quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I feel that you don't care and I feel you're being insensitive are not feelings, and that's where we make our biggest mistakes when it comes to feedback.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A practical feedback rule: separate actual emotions from interpretations/judgments to reduce miscommunication and conflict.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Questions that start with what, when, where, how. Stay away from why.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A concrete questioning framework to lower defensiveness and keep conversations focused on observable specifics rather than perceived motives.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We don't understand that we are only privy to two out of the three, so I know what's going on for me and I know what I did. I have no idea what happened on your end.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: The “three realities” model highlights the blind spot in interpersonal conflict: you can’t directly know the other person’s experience.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What a disservice to not help people understand that anger is a distancing emotion and there are other emotions that are connecting.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive emotional reframe: treating anger as distancing encourages leaders to surface more connecting emotions to repair relationships.

quotes.topic_title: Why robust relationships matter; relationship continuum
quotes.text: I think that most people experience a richer, fuller, more meaningful life when they have at least some high quality relationships or maybe put the other way. If you have none, it's unlikely you're going to experience quite as rich and full a life.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Frames high-quality relationships as a foundational ingredient for a meaningful life, motivating intentional relationship-building.

quotes.topic_title: Why robust relationships matter; relationship continuum
quotes.text: So I often talk about relationships exist on a continuum. At one end of the continuum is contact and no connection, or we could also say dysfunction.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Introduces a practical mental model (a continuum) for diagnosing where a relationship currently sits and what “progress” looks like.

quotes.topic_title: Why robust relationships matter; relationship continuum
quotes.text: And by the way, contact no connection. Those are thousands of Facebook friends. Those are not relationships and those are not friends in my vocabulary.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that lots of online connections equate to real relationships.

quotes.topic_title: Why robust relationships matter; relationship continuum
quotes.text: But it turns out that the skills you need to move along that continuum actually take you from contact and no connection and dysfunction to at least functional and robust.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Emphasizes that relationship skills are transferable and can reliably upgrade relationships to a healthier baseline.

quotes.topic_title: Why robust relationships matter; relationship continuum
quotes.text: And I believe if we had a critical mass of human beings on this planet who had those skills and knew how to get to at least robust and functional, we wouldn't just have more functional teams and organizations, we'd have stronger communities, we'd have more functional schools. We might, in my wildest dreams, even have a more functional government.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Connects individual relationship competence to large-scale outcomes in organizations and society, expanding the stakes of the framework.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of stronger relationships in life and work
quotes.text: the premise of the course is that people do business with people not ideas, not products, not machines, not tactics, strategies, not even money, they do business with people. So you better get the people part right if you really want to succeed.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive business framework that elevates relationship skill as the core driver of outcomes over products, strategy, or capital.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of stronger relationships in life and work
quotes.text: And that interpersonal competence is a determinant of both personal and professional success.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A succinct mental model for prioritizing interpersonal skill-building as a high-leverage investment across life and work.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of stronger relationships in life and work
quotes.text: I've lost track of how many hundreds of emails and calls and visits I've had from former students who come to tell me I just became a CEO. I'm pretty sure I owe it all to you. I just raised my third round. I'm pretty sure I owe it all to you.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Concrete outcome examples suggesting relationship competence can materially impact leadership attainment and fundraising success.

quotes.topic_title: Benefits of stronger relationships in life and work
quotes.text: even more rewarding for me are the, "I'm pretty sure your class just saved my marriage." I just reconciled my relationship with my brother who I hadn't talked to for two years because he voted for X and I voted for Y.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Illustrates spillover benefits of relationship skills into high-stakes personal relationships, including conflict repair and reconciliation.

quotes.topic_title: What “Touchy Feely” teaches leaders
quotes.text: People learn how to be more interpersonally competent or how to connect with other people in more functional ways.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Defines the core skill the course builds—practical interpersonal competence as a learnable capability.

quotes.topic_title: What “Touchy Feely” teaches leaders
quotes.text: And what I mean by connect is learn how I need to show up in order for you to trust me, in order for you to feel closer to me, in order for you to want to spend more time with me in a leadership.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Offers an actionable model of “connection” as specific behaviors that increase trust, closeness, and followership.

quotes.topic_title: What “Touchy Feely” teaches leaders
quotes.text: in the end, that's the question leaders should ask themselves, "Why should somebody follow me?"
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A memorable leadership self-audit question that reframes leadership as earned influence rather than title.

quotes.topic_title: What “Touchy Feely” teaches leaders
quotes.text: But if you want to build a sustainable long-term legacy, then you probably want to think about showing up in a way that other people come to see you as a referent figure, somebody in their life that they say, "When I grow up, I want to be more like that."
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Introduces “referent figure” as a long-term leadership aim—becoming someone others aspire to emulate.

quotes.topic_title: What “Touchy Feely” teaches leaders
quotes.text: And that is a form of power. There's a lot of research that supports this, referent power.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Names a research-backed power base (referent power) that leaders can intentionally cultivate through how they show up.

quotes.topic_title: Experiential learning: T-groups and disclosure practice
quotes.text: I don't learn how to connect with you by reading about it in a book
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Emphasizes that relationship skills require practice and lived experience, not just intellectual understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Experiential learning: T-groups and disclosure practice
quotes.text: But most of the learning happens in these small groups called T groups. The T stands for training, not therapy.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Introduces a practical methodology (T-groups) and clarifies the mental model: skill-building training rather than therapy.

quotes.topic_title: Experiential learning: T-groups and disclosure practice
quotes.text: Allow the other person to get to know you. And that's the only instruction I give.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage exercise prompt that forces participants to notice and experiment with their default interaction patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Experiential learning: T-groups and disclosure practice
quotes.text: take a moment and recognize that you just had a bunch of choices that you actually probably never even think about.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Highlights the core practice loop: reflect on micro-choices in conversation to deliberately improve relational outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Experiential learning: T-groups and disclosure practice
quotes.text: one of the ways we build relationships is through disclosure, through allowing ourselves to become more known.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Names a concrete mechanism for deepening relationships that practitioners can apply immediately: calibrated self-disclosure.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders in Tech programs and how to join
quotes.text: And what we're trying to do is we're trying to influence the cultures of the future of Facebook's and Google's of the world, not the current ones.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A clear strategic lens for leadership development: shape culture upstream by investing in earlier-stage companies and leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders in Tech programs and how to join
quotes.text: But if you just buy the book and you read it and you put it back on your shelf, you're not going to learn anything. Don't waste your money.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that relationship skills require practice, not passive consumption—useful for anyone relying on reading alone.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders in Tech programs and how to join
quotes.text: If you're going to buy the book, buy at least one other copy and give it to somebody with whom you actually want to develop a stronger relationship and read it together and do the activities at the end of every book, and then you start to get a taste of what it's like to go through the course.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A concrete, immediately actionable method for applying the material: co-learning with a specific relationship and doing the exercises.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders in Tech programs and how to join
quotes.text: You have to be nominated in order to apply. Don't let that stop you. If you look at it all and you decide you want to apply, just apply and say, Carole, I listened to Carole Robin on this podcast, you told me to apply.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Practical guidance for overcoming a common application barrier by using a direct, permission-based approach.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders in Tech programs and how to join
quotes.text: Don't waste time trying to find somebody to nominate you.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive process advice: prioritize momentum over gatekeeping steps that often become procrastination traps.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive disclosure and the 15% rule
quotes.text: So first of all, when we disclose, we make ourselves more vulnerable, and vulnerability and disclosure tend to be reciprocal. If I hold my cards really close, you're going to hold your cards even closer.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Highlights the reciprocity dynamic: your level of openness directly shapes how open the other person will be.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive disclosure and the 15% rule
quotes.text: So one of the things to learn to do is to experiment.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Frames relationship-deepening as iterative testing rather than a one-size-fits-all script.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive disclosure and the 15% rule
quotes.text: And you have to step outside your comfort zone in order to learn anything, and especially in order to create a deeper connection with somebody.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Connects personal growth and relational depth to deliberately moving beyond what feels safe or routine.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive disclosure and the 15% rule
quotes.text: So we came up with the 15% rule. So step a little bit outside your comfort zone. If you step a little bit outside your comfort zone, you're very unlikely to freak yourself or the other person out.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Introduces a practical calibration method for vulnerability that reduces the risk of oversharing or triggering defensiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Progressive disclosure and the 15% rule
quotes.text: But you'll know, you'll feel it a little bit, you'll be like, okay, I feel just a little uncomfortable saying this, but I think I'm going to try.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Gives a simple internal signal practitioners can use to identify the “learning zone” in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Appropriate vulnerability in leadership
quotes.text: Well, of course, context matters. It depends on who I'm talking to. And by the way, disclosure, I want to underscore a concept that we also very much teach, which is appropriate disclosure.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework for leaders: vulnerability should be calibrated to context rather than maximized.

quotes.topic_title: Appropriate vulnerability in leadership
quotes.text: That might be vulnerable and disclosure, but it is not appropriate Vulnerability and that it's not what we're talking about.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Draws a clear boundary between helpful vulnerability and credibility-damaging oversharing.

quotes.topic_title: Appropriate vulnerability in leadership
quotes.text: And man, I wish I could stand up here and tell you I know exactly what's happening and I know exactly what we should do about it, but I don't, and I have never needed you all more.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Gives a concrete script for admitting uncertainty while mobilizing the team and strengthening followership.

quotes.topic_title: Appropriate vulnerability in leadership
quotes.text: Now, I ask you, how do you inspire anybody with no feelings? How do you motivate anybody with no feelings? How do you become seen as a real person with no feelings?
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Challenges the “leave feelings at the door” norm by linking emotional presence to inspiration and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Appropriate vulnerability in leadership
quotes.text: I actually think that a leader who is willing to be appropriately vulnerable is a stronger leader.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: States the counterintuitive leadership principle that appropriate vulnerability increases strength rather than diminishing authority.

quotes.topic_title: Vulnerability story: becoming a real leader
quotes.text: I actually think that a leader who is willing to be appropriately vulnerable is a stronger leader.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A contrarian leadership principle that reframes vulnerability as a source of strength when used appropriately.

quotes.topic_title: Vulnerability story: becoming a real leader
quotes.text: Let's start with you can start admitting mistakes, especially when everybody knows you made one, you actually lose a lot more credibility by ignoring it.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Concrete, immediately applicable advice for building trust by acknowledging errors rather than trying to hide them.

quotes.topic_title: Vulnerability story: becoming a real leader
quotes.text: And you can start again 15% by experimenting with sharing what's going on for you, particularly with regard to feelings a little bit more often.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A practical “small steps” methodology (15% disclosure) for increasing vulnerability without overcorrecting.

quotes.topic_title: Vulnerability story: becoming a real leader
quotes.text: Feelings give meaning to facts.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model explaining why emotional disclosure deepens understanding beyond just sharing information.

quotes.topic_title: Vulnerability story: becoming a real leader
quotes.text: To this day, I believe that was the day I became a leader.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A pivotal example showing how an emotional moment can transform team connection and leadership legitimacy.

quotes.topic_title: Feelings vocabulary; anger as secondary emotion
quotes.text: Let's start with you can start admitting mistakes, especially when everybody knows you made one, you actually lose a lot more credibility by ignoring it.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Practical leadership advice: acknowledging obvious mistakes preserves credibility more than pretending they didn’t happen.

quotes.topic_title: Feelings vocabulary; anger as secondary emotion
quotes.text: It starts with allowing yourself to be known, not just in terms of facts and... Feelings give meaning to facts.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A core framework for deeper relationships: facts alone are insufficient; emotions provide the meaning that builds connection.

quotes.topic_title: Feelings vocabulary; anger as secondary emotion
quotes.text: part of what you taught us was that anger is often a secondary emotion and often under anger is either fear or hurt.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A useful emotional model for leaders: reframe anger as a surface signal pointing to more vulnerable underlying feelings.

quotes.topic_title: Feelings vocabulary; anger as secondary emotion
quotes.text: And he said, "I have never had my troops rally to fix something faster."
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Concrete leadership outcome: naming fear instead of expressing anger produced faster alignment and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Feelings vocabulary; anger as secondary emotion
quotes.text: And anger is a distancing emotion, whereas hurt, fear, sadness, loneliness, happiness, joy are all connecting emotions.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive distinction leaders can apply: some emotions create distance (anger) while others increase connection and trust.

quotes.topic_title: Mental models that limit connection and feedback
quotes.text: And mental models, then we developed them very early and they're grooved and we need new experiences in order to even believe that they're maybe subject to testing.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Highlights why outdated beliefs persist and why deliberate new experiences are required to update them.

quotes.topic_title: Mental models that limit connection and feedback
quotes.text: It's like I have a colleague who often says, we have to think about these things as dials, not switches.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model for calibrating vulnerability/ disclosure gradually rather than all-or-nothing.

quotes.topic_title: Mental models that limit connection and feedback
quotes.text: It does not mean feedback ruins relationships. It means feedback the way you've always seen it done or done. It ruins relationships pretty important.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Reframes a common fear by separating “feedback” from the harmful ways people typically deliver it.

quotes.topic_title: Mental models that limit connection and feedback
quotes.text: That's why we call it talk about a pinch before it becomes a crunch, and then it becomes a much bigger deal.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Provides a memorable method for addressing small irritations early to prevent escalation and resentment.

quotes.topic_title: Mental models that limit connection and feedback
quotes.text: So I always tell students, okay, substitute the pronoun, substitute the word it for I, you, we. I'm not worth it, you're not worth it. We're not worth it. And then ask yourself again whether it's worth raising.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Gives a concrete self-check to challenge avoidance and recognize the relational cost of staying silent.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Every week on this podcast, you get to hear from product leaders and growth experts from some of the world's most impactful companies, whether it's Airbnb, Slack, Figma, or Stripe.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete examples of the kinds of operators and companies featured, useful for practitioners seeking high-signal learning sources.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But what will the next wave of companies look like?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A framing question that encourages forward-looking thinking rather than only studying past winners.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: From drones to DNA to deep learning, you can eavesdrop on the future with the a16z Podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable positioning statement that highlights breadth across emerging tech domains.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yeah. And in fact, it is fundamental to giving feedback.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Signals that the upcoming “three realities and the net” concept is a core framework for effective feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Two antennae and the three realities framework
quotes.text: we're all equipped with two antennae. One is tracking what's going on for me, my internal antenna. The other one is trying to pick up signals on what might be going on for you.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Introduces the “two antennae” model for balancing self-awareness with attunement to others.

quotes.topic_title: Two antennae and the three realities framework
quotes.text: first of all, recognizing those two antennae exist. Second of all, learning how to hone our ability to pick up subtler and subtler signals make us more interpersonally competent.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Gives a practical skill progression: notice the antennas, then deliberately improve signal detection.

quotes.topic_title: Two antennae and the three realities framework
quotes.text: It starts with in any exchange between two people, there are three realities. There is my intent, how I see the world, my background, my history, there is what I do or say or don't do, verbal or nonverbal.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Defines the “three realities” framework as the foundation for giving feedback well.

quotes.topic_title: Two antennae and the three realities framework
quotes.text: And the trouble we get into when we don't recognize that those three realities exist is we don't understand that we are only privy to two out of the three.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Highlights a common feedback failure mode: assuming access to the other person’s internal experience.

quotes.topic_title: Two antennae and the three realities framework
quotes.text: And anybody who's ever taken Touchy Feely in no matter which context knows the saying, "Stay on your side of the net."
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Provides a memorable rule-of-thumb for sticking to what you can actually know (intent + behavior) in feedback conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback formula to reduce defensiveness
quotes.text: Meaning stick with the two realities you know because we get in trouble the minute we start thinking we know the other person's reality.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A practical boundary-setting rule for feedback: describe only observable behavior and your internal experience, not the other person’s intent.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback formula to reduce defensiveness
quotes.text: And I feel that you don't care and I feel you're being insensitive are not feelings. They're attributions and imputed motives, and that's where we make our biggest mistakes when it comes to feedback.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A diagnostic for defensiveness: “feel” statements that smuggle in judgments/intent are likely to escalate conflict.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback formula to reduce defensiveness
quotes.text: So the formula is when you do insert behavior, I feel pull out the vocabulary of feelings and I'm telling you this because, or I'm hoping the outcome of you knowing this is.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A clear, repeatable feedback structure that shifts conversations from blame to collaborative problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback formula to reduce defensiveness
quotes.text: And by the way, that is the purpose of feedback. When it's constructive feedback, move into a problem-solving conversation, don't change the other person. Move into behaviors that will work better for both of you.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: Reframes feedback away from fixing people and toward jointly designing better behaviors and agreements.

quotes.topic_title: Feedback formula to reduce defensiveness
quotes.text: Because often we say it takes two to know one, I don't know what impact I'm having on you until you tell me.
quotes.speaker: Carole Robin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why feedback is necessary: you can’t accurately infer your impact without the other person’s data.
